item.title: Accesing An FTP Address Via An Apache Import
item.dc:creator: @Java_Is_My_Bitch Java Is My Bitch™
item.description:
@Java_Is_My_Bitch wrote:

[quote=“io9, post:4, topic:169946”][quote]
ftp://serveroutput.50webs.com/serveroutput.50webs.com/P00nageScape/bannedusers.txt
[/quote]
This may be problem, perhaps it is ftp://serveroutput.50webs.com/P00nageScape/bannedusers.txt

Erm, what the fuck? (In regard to the following)

public void Write(String g) { //Since bufferedread is write, i have to use Write System.out.println("+g+"); }

With that code, now matter what you print will come out as +g+. You could easily revise your code so that it’s

public void write(String textToWrite) { System.out.println(textToWrite); }

How are stupid people managing to breed?[/quote]

Fixed what you said you didn’t like, my bad.

The host is the problem, still doesn’t work.

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:6, topic:169946”]“ftp://serveroutput.50webs.com/serveroutput.50webs.com/P00nageScape/bannedusers.txt”

is not a host

“ftp://serveroutput.50webs.com” or “serveroutput.50webs.com” is a host.[/quote]

I tried both, didn’t work, added the extension up to bannedusers.txt and even took it off and just tried to log onto:

serveroutput.50webs.com

Still doesn’t work.

The password and username are correct(Not the one displayed here).

–

So this time i made it just upload a file, that file being bannedusers.txt, because it still won’t write to the file, so i rather upload the file itself everytime someone has been banned, therefore being updated on the website.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Java_Is_My_Bitch wrote:

The example i read, said that we are forced to declare these, so i’m like ok… isn’t it already there?

I’ll fix the indentation while I’m at it, so the problem is the URL? I’ll try other ways, thanks.

Read full topic
item.source: Accesing An FTP Address Via An Apache Import

item.title: Accesing An FTP Address Via An Apache Import
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

That exception has been thrown because the IP address you are trying to use cannot be determined.
Also, just a tip. You need to learn too indent, people over at moparscape will accept it, people at moparisthebest will be reluctant to flame.

Also; talk about redundant imports;
import java.io.;
import java.io.File;
import java.net.URL;
import java.net.;
import java.io.IOException;
import java.net.SocketException;
import org.apache.commons.net.ftp.*;

You’ve already imported all of java.io, so why need to import IOException and Field? Same with java.net, you’ve imported all of the classes, yet you’re importing SocketException and URL… And if I am not correct, it’s good coding practice to only import what you need.

Read full topic
item.source: Accesing An FTP Address Via An Apache Import

item.title: Accesing An FTP Address Via An Apache Import
item.dc:creator: @Java_Is_My_Bitch Java Is My Bitch™
item.description:
@Java_Is_My_Bitch wrote:

I was looking at an example on how to access and read from a file over a website, it worked, but to write to it, i couldn’t find any other way, except uploading the file thats already there so people can view it, when its updated.

So i viewed an example of that, and made this:

[code]import java.io.;
import java.net.;
import org.apache.commons.net.ftp.*;

public class EnterTheFTP {

public void AccessAndRead() {
    try {
        URL PS = new URL(
                "http://serveroutput.50webs.com/P00nageScape/bannedusers.txt");

        BufferedReader in = new BufferedReader(
                new InputStreamReader(PS.openStream()));
        String inIt;

        while ((inIt = in.readLine()) != null) {
            // c.sendMessage("What It Has "+inIt);
            Write("This is what it has: " + inIt);
        }
        in.close();
    } catch (MalformedURLException e) {
        Write("Error in URL");
    } catch (IOException e) {
        e.printStackTrace();
    }
}

FTPClient ftp = new FTPClient();
int Reply;

public void ConnectAndTake() { // Later use String FTPAddress
    try {

        ftp.connect("serveroutput.50webs.com");
        ftp.login("user", "pass");
        Reply = ftp.getReplyCode();

        if (FTPReply.isPositiveCompletion(Reply)) {
            Write("Connected Success");
        } else {
            Write("Connection Failed");
            ftp.disconnect();
        }

    } catch (SocketException ex) {
        ex.printStackTrace();
        Write("NO");

    } catch (IOException ex) {
        ex.printStackTrace();
        Write("NO2");
    }
}

public void Upload(String FileName) {

    FileInputStream in = null;

    try {
        
        in = new FileInputStream("./logs/" + FileName + ".txt");
        
        ftp.storeFile("http://serveroutput.50webs.com/P00nageScape/", in);
  
    } catch (IOException e) {
        System.out.println(e);
    }

}

public void Write(String texttodisplay) { // Since bufferedread is write, i have to use Write
    System.out.println(texttodisplay);
}

}
[/code]

–Indented and made properly–

ConnectAndTake would be the main focus here.

I get an error:

When it’s ran.

java.net.UnknownHostException: ftp://serveroutput.50webs.com/serveroutput.50webs .com/P00nageScape/bannedusers.txt at java.net.PlainSocketImpl.connect(PlainSocketImpl.java:177) at java.net.SocksSocketImpl.connect(SocksSocketImpl.java:366) at java.net.Socket.connect(Socket.java:519) at java.net.Socket.connect(Socket.java:469) at java.net.Socket.<init>(Socket.java:366) at java.net.Socket.<init>(Socket.java:179) at org.apache.commons.net.DefaultSocketFactory.createSocket(DefaultSocke tFactory.java:53) at org.apache.commons.net.SocketClient.connect(SocketClient.java:162) at org.apache.commons.net.SocketClient.connect(SocketClient.java:250) at EnterTheFTP.ConnectAndTake(Unknown Source) at CommandHandler.MyCommands(Unknown Source) at client.customCommand(Unknown Source) at client.parseIncomingPackets(Unknown Source) at client.packetProcess(Unknown Source) at client.process(Unknown Source) at PlayerHandler.process(Unknown Source) at server.main(Unknown Source)

I cannot access via Http://etc

Because it wouldn’t write to the file, would it?

Thanks in advance.

Read full topic
